assisted  by  a  full  time  project  manager  and  a  team  of  qualified

Goods  and  works  financed  by  the  ADB  grant  will  be  procured  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as 
amended from time to time). Civil works for the project road will be 
procured through international competitive bidding. Equipment will 
be procured through national competitive bidding. 
 
The  Project  will  finance  92.5  person-months  of  international 
consulting  services:  16  for  detailed  design,  72  for  construction 
supervision, and 4.5 for other services. The detailed design period 
is anticipated to begin in the first quarter of 2008 and last for the 
entire  year.  The  construction  supervision  consulting  services  will 
be  required  from  the  middle  of  the  second  quarter  of  2009  and 
extend  through  the  completion  of  the  road  defects  liability  period 
at  the  end  of  the  third  quarter  of  2013.  The  Government  will 
finance  consulting  services  for  detailed  design,  while  ADB  will 
finance  the  construction  supervision  consulting  services.  The 
ADB-financed consultants will be recruited using quality- and cost-
based selection (80% technical and 20% financial weighting) and 
full  technical  proposal,  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Guidelines  on 
the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
 
The  Project  will  (i)  improve  the  transport  network  in  the  region, 
allowing  residents  easier,  less  expensive,  and  faster  access  to 
social, health, and other services; (ii) increase the annual regional 
gross domestic product of Hovd aimag to 6% after completion of 
the  Project;  (iii)  help  increase  regional  transit  trade  tonnage 
through Mongolia’s western region by 25% by 2014; and (iv) help 
increase trade between the western region and the PRC and the 
Russian  Federation  by  15%  by  2013.  Income  of  targeted 
participants  of  the  Project  is  expected  to  increase  10%  annually. 
The expected results of the Project include (i) reduced travel time 
from Yarant to Hovd aimag center by 3 hours by 2013, (ii) reduced 
average  border  processing  times  for  goods  and  passengers  at 
Yarant  by  1  hour  by  2013,  and  (iii)  traffic  volume  at  the  Yarant 
border  increased  by  15%  annually  from  2012  to  2015.  The 
economic internal rate of return for the Project is 16.3%.

traders,  and  transport  providers,  as  well  as  local  economies  and 
labor.  The  environment  of  the  region  will  be  improved  through 
reduction of dust generated by vehicles traveling over earth roads 
and elimination of multiple earthen tracks that currently exist along 
the  proposed  alignment.  A  considerable  number  of  jobs  will  be

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to  Mongolia  for  the  Western  Regional  Road  Corridor  Development  Project–Phase  I  (the 
Project). The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

Mongolia has a relatively large land mass and small population, resulting in one of the 
2. 
lowest  population  densities  in  the  world;  less  than  1.5  per  square  kilometer  in  most  of  the 
country.  Due  to  its  large  geographic  area  and  relatively  low  population  density,  Mongolia’s 
transport  system  is  generally  not  well  developed.  Residents  of  remote  rural  areas  lack 
reasonable access to markets and social services, and are isolated from the country’s political 
and economic centers due to the poor road network. Within Mongolia, the far western aimags1 
are the most affected. 
 
Furthermore,  Mongolia’s  geographic  location,  far  from  the  sea  and  surrounded  by  two 
3. 
large  neighbors—the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  and  the  Russian  Federation—makes 
external  transport  links via  these  countries  very  significant  in  terms  of  Mongolia’s  international 
trade.  A  detailed  road  subsector  analysis  is  in  Appendix  2.  To  create  favorable  conditions  to 
access  the  sea,  improve  the  efficiency  of  transit  transportation  through  the  territory  of  foreign 
counties,  and  increase  transit  transportation  through  Mongolia,  the  Government  of  Mongolia 
(the Government) has decided to build key roads within Mongolia. The Government’s national 
development  strategy  based  on  the  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs)  identifies  three 
main road corridors as priority projects for development; all are sections of the Asian Highway 
Network.2 The proposed road corridor, which is part of Asian Highway 4 (AH4), between Yarant 
at the PRC border and Ulaanbaishint at the Russian border, is one of the priority development 
projects for Mongolia and is included in national and regional3 development plans. The Project 
will develop the road section from Yarant to Hovd aimag center on the proposed road corridor. 
 
4. 
The  Asian  Highway  Network  is  a  system  of  141,000  kilometers  (km)  of  standardized 
roads  crossing  32  Asian  countries  with  linkages  to  Europe  and  Central  Asia  endorsed  by  the 
United  Nations  Economic  and  Social  Commission  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific.  AH4  will  join 
Mongolia  initially  with  the  PRC  and  the  Russian  Federation,  and  then  continue  to  link  the 
country  with  neighboring  Central  Asian  countries  such  as  Kazakhstan.  The  proposed  cross-
border linkage will help Mongolia improve its trade with Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region of 
the  PRC  (Xinjiang)  and  Siberia  in  the  Russian  Federation.  It  will  also  help  to  improve  tourism 
and tourism-related businesses in western Mongolia.

5. 
Road  Network  in  Mongolia.  Mongolia’s  road  network,  including  both  state  and  local 
roads,  totals  approximately  49,250  km  connecting  21  major  cities  and  towns  and  160  smaller 
villages (soums [local administrative area] and bags [local administrative subdivisions]). Of this 
total,  state  roads  account  for  11,219  km,  and  aimag  and  local  roads  for  38,031  km.  Most 
Mongolian roads are gravel and earth; approximately 3.5% of the road network is paved.

Within the western region, transport infrastructure is limited. Within the two most western

aimags, Bayan-Olgiy allocates 0.31% of its land for the formal transportation network and Hovd 
allocates 0.2%. These percentages do not take into account the large number of unofficial earth 
tracks.  As  demonstrated  by  an  analysis  of  the  current  makeup  of  the  road  alignment,  of  the 
748.4  km  of  the  proposed  road  corridor,  104.3  km  are  gravel,  181.2  km  are  improved  road

from the Mongolia-PRC border. The project impact area of phase I comprises Hovd aimag. 
 
7. 
Road Subsector Financing. The road subsector is financed from the state budget and 
three  types  of  road  funds:  State  Road  Fund,  21  local  (aimag)  road  funds,  and  Urban  Road 
Fund.  In  accordance  with  the  1995  Law  on  Fuel  Tax  on  Gasoline  and  Diesel,  road  fund 
revenues comprise (i) allocations of a part of fuel taxes on gasoline and diesel; (ii) state budget 
allocations;  and  (iii)  other  donations  and  contributions  such  as  private  donations  to  the 
Millennium Road, fines, fees, and miscellaneous revenue. However, only the State Road Fund 
receives an allocation from the fuel taxes collected; the other two types of funds depend entirely 
on vehicle licensing taxes and allocations from aimag or municipal governments. 
 
8. 
In recent years, State Road Fund revenues have not been sufficient to meet the needs 
of the Department of Roads of the Ministry of Roads, Transport and Tourism (MRTT). In 2005, 
MNT22.18  billion  were  allocated  to  the  State  Road  Fund.  In  2004,  1.4%  of  Mongolia’s  gross

21.  Mongolia’s  landlocked  location  between  the  PRC  and  the  Russian  Federation,  and  its 
remoteness  from  developed  international  and  domestic  markets  are  major  constraints  to

surrounding  environment,  population,  and  traffic  movements.15 These  goals  and  strategies  are

THE PROPOSED PROJECT 

A. 

Impact and Outcome 

26. 
The  impact  of  the  Project  will  be  the  promotion  of  regional  transport  of  freight  and 
passengers via the Western Regional Road Corridor and increased economic development and 
regional  trade.  The  outcome  will  be  an  efficient  and  safe  regional  transport  route  that  is 
developed  in  the  western  region  of  Mongolia,  linking  Xinjiang  in  the  PRC  and  Siberia  in  the 
Russian  Federation,  by  way  of  Hovd  and  Bayan-Olgiy  aimags  in  Mongolia.  The  project  road 
represents  a  portion  of  the  AH4,  an  internationally  designated  road  by  the  United  Nations 
Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific.  
 
27. 
The  growth  of  gross  regional  product  for  western  Mongolia  for  2003–2005  was  around 
3%; less than 50% of the gross national product for Mongolia (7.5%) for the same period. Once 
the  Project  is  implemented,  the  gross  regional  product  for  western  Mongolia  is  expected  to 
increase  at  rates  between  4.5%  and  7.0%  per  year  through  2035.  Additionally,  the  gross 
regional product per capita growth rates are anticipated to range between 4.5% and 5.6% over 
the  same  time  horizon.  Employment  opportunities  will  increase  and  out-migration  will  decline, 
resulting  in  an  annual  rate  of  population  increase  between  1.0%  and  1.5%.  If  additional 
improvements are made to the border facilities, growth figures are expected to be even higher. 
 
28. 
In addition to stimulating economic growth within Hovd aimag, the aims of project road 
construction include (i) regional transit trade tonnages increase by 25% during 2007–2014 and 
(ii)  trade  between  the  western  region  and  the  PRC  increases  by  15%  during  2007–2014. 
Specific goals relating to transport of passengers and freight along the route include (i) average 
speed  on  the  road  increases  from  40  km  per  hour  to  60  km  per  hour  by  2013;  (ii)  travel  time 
from  Yarant  to  Hovd  aimag  center  decreases  by  3  hours  by  2013;  (iii)  average  border 
processing  times  for  goods  and  passengers  at  Yarant  decreases  by  1  hour  by  2013,  and 
(iv) traffic volume at the Yarant border increases by 15% annually from 2012 to 2015.

37. 
Regional  Cooperation.  As  a  large  landlocked  country,  Mongolia  depends  on  its  two 
neighbors,  the  PRC  and  the  Russian  Federation,  for  access  to  world  markets  and  economic 
development.  The  PRC  and  the  Russian  Federation  dominate  Mongolia’s  external  trade. 
However,  lack  of  roads  leading  to  the  PRC  and  the  Russian  Federation  is  a  constraint.  The 
majority  of  Mongolia’s  external  trade  is  carried  on  the  existing  north–south  rail  line,  which 
connects  Suhbaatar  at  the  border  with  the  Russian  Federation  and  Zamyn-Uud  at  the  border 
with the PRC. The ongoing road development along the rail line (footnote 19) will help improve 
Mongolia’s flexibility and limited capacity to handle exports and imports with its neighbors. Even 
after  this  development,  Mongolia  will  have  only  one  paved  road  corridor  connecting  north  and 
south. To improve its trade and tourism, Mongolia needs a number of similar road corridors. The 
Western  Regional  Road  Corridor  is  considered  as  the  next  most  important  trade  link  to 
Mongolia.  
 
38. 
The  Project  will  develop  a  part  of  Mongolia’s  second  north–south  paved  road  corridor 
link, which is part of the Asian Highway Network. The route is identified as AH4. From the north, 
the AH4 will connect western Mongolia to Barnaul and Novosibirsk in east-central Siberia in the 
Russian Federation and from the south it will connect to Urumqi in Xinjiang. Moving westward 
from both Barnaul and Xinjiang, the AH4 will connect to several other AH roads that will link with 
Central Asian countries such as Kazakhstan and Kyrgyz Republic. These connections will help 
to link western Mongolia to the entire region.

and facilitating trade in western Mongolia. Mongolia’s participation in this organization and the 
proximity of other members that are experiencing strong economic growth cycles (e.g., the PRC 
and Kazakhstan) provide increased opportunities for both interregional and international trade.

Under the Project, the Yarant–Bulgan–Hovd section of the road will be completed. The

B. 

Economic Analysis 

62. 
Construction  of  the  road  will  provide  a  large  stimulus  to  the  economy  through  the 
estimated $112.22 million project cost. Once the road is in place, the cost of transportation will 
be  lower,  and  hence,  business  costs  will  be  lower,  providing  an  ongoing  stimulus  to  the 

 

 14 

 

economy. The cost of imported goods will decrease and the net realization from exports mainly 
connected with animal husbandry will increase, thereby improving terms of trade for Mongolia. 
Moreover,  as  this  area  of  the  country  has  little  industry  and  almost  no  import-competing 
industry, very few offsetting losses can be anticipated. Like many developing regions, western 
Mongolia has relied on local cheap natural resources as the basis for the little industrial activity 
that exists. Thus, an abundance of land became the source of a livestock industry, which in turn 
led  to  meat  processing,  fiber  production  (cashmere  and  wool),  and  hides  and  skins.  The 
opportunity for future expansion of the number of livestock is limited because overgrazing and 
desertification  already  present  problems.  The  new  road  will  improve  the  situation,  as  it  will 
reduce the large number of parallel dirt tracks (up to 100 on some open stretches of the existing 
alignment), which are highly destructive to surface vegetation. 
 
Economic  viability  mainly  depending  on  projected  traffic  flow  is  more  realistically 
63. 
analyzed for the entire proposed road corridor rather than phase I (the Project) only. The overall 
economic internal rate of return (EIRR) is estimated by comparing the project case with a base 
case. The Project, with shorter travel time, safer design, and better road conditions, will reduce 
vehicle operating costs and accident risks along the corridor. The economic costs are the cost 
of capital, which includes physical contingencies, land acquisition, and the cost of operating and 
maintaining  the  project  roads,  including  the  replacement  of  depreciated  equipment.  Economic 
benefits  include  (i)  savings  in  vehicle  operating  costs  resulting  from  the  shorter  distance  and 
improved road conditions, (ii) time savings for road users, and (iii) trade-related benefits through 
cross-border facilitation. At 16.3% per year, the EIRR demonstrates the economic viability of the 
proposed  road  corridor.  Results  of  the  sensitivity  analysis  confirm  the  robustness  of  the 
economic viability. Even with changes in the key variables such as construction costs, reduction 
in  traffic  volume,  and  project  delay  by  1  year,  the  EIRR  is  above  the  cutoff  rate  of  12%.  The 
results suggest that costs would need to increase by 49.4% to reduce the EIRR to 12%, while 
benefits would need to be reduced by 33.1% to reduce the EIRR to 12% (Appendix 15). 
 
For phase I (the Project) only, under which only the Yarant–Bulgan–Hovd section will be 
64. 
completed, the EIRR is estimated to be 13.6%, which is still economically viable but lower than 
the EIRR for the entire proposed road corridor. Although the road is upgraded for the section of 
Yarant–Bulgan–Hovd  by  the  completion  of  phase  I,  the  amount  of  induced  international  and 
local traffic will be affected, compared with the original traffic forecast where the entire road is 
completed.  This  will  lead  to  deferment  of  achieving  economic  benefits  and,  in  turn,  forces  the 
EIRR of phase I to be lower than the EIRR of the entire road corridor.

65.

cross-border trade between Mongolia and the PRC under a regional TA.25 The TA outputs will

ROAD SAFETY IN MONGOLIA 

 
1. 
Mongolia  has  a  serious  road  traffic  safety  problem;  traffic  accidents  have  a  significant 
economic cost, as well as social and personal impacts on victims and their families. The number 
of  accidents  increased  nearly  7  times  between  1995  and  2006,  from  860  to  5,911.  Fatalities 
from  road  accidents  in  urban  areas  increased  by  28.6%;  injuries  increased  by  approximately 
46.2%.  In  rural  areas,  accidents  increased  by  27.7%,  while  deaths  remained  relatively 
unchanged and injuries increased by 34.2%. Rural areas accounted for approximately one fifth 
of  total  accidents  and  two  thirds  of  deaths  nationally.  In  this  respect,  rural  areas  are  a  more 
significant source of road accident fatalities. 
 
2. 
The analysis of national data on accidents and vehicle ownership shows that while the 
number  of  accidents  per  1,000  vehicles  increased  more  than  27.7%  in  the  12-year  period, 
deaths  per  1,000  vehicles  decreased  by  9.3%  and  injuries  by  7.1%.  In  terms  of  severity, 
national statistics show the following trend: deaths resulting from accidents between 1995 and 
2006 remained relatively unchanged (0.34 and 0.33); injuries decreased from 1.01 to 0.25. 
 
3. 
The  Road  Law  and  Road  Transport  Law  detail  the  duties  and  functions  of  each 
administrative  level  to  ensure  that  roads  are  properly  maintained  and  the  traffic  flow  is  well-
managed and safe for the general public. 
 
4. 
Road  Safety  Issues.  With  the  exception  of  the  southernmost  64  kilometers  at  the 
People’s  Republic  of  China–Mongolia  border  and  short  sections  passing  through  Hovd  and 
Olgiy and at the Russian Federation border, the project road is not paved, making vehicle travel 
difficult, particularly for large trucks crossing the mountain passes. Road safety is a concern in 
hilly and mountainous areas as vehicles try  to maneuver around bends where sight lines may 
be limited. 
 
In  populated  areas,  speeding  vehicles  and  the  presence  of  pedestrians  and  livestock 
5. 
unwary  of  oncoming  traffic  pose  a  safety  threat.  With  the  proposed  road  upgrading  and 
improvement, both traffic volume and speed will increase, correspondingly heightening the risk 
of road accidents.  
 
6. 
The  road  segment  from  Bulgan  soum  [local  administrative  division]  to  the  junction  for 
Must soum is approximately 170 kilometers and covers a wide range of topography. It includes 
a river crossing of Uyench River, currently without a bridge; a river valley along Bodonch River 
with  nine  bridges  crossing  the  river;  and  a  2,860-meter  mountain  pass.  The  alignment  of  the 
section  has  numerous  very  sharp  horizontal  curves  with  limited  sight  distances  in  narrow 
sections. This road segment will require alignment modifications to provide a wider carriageway 
and better horizontal radii and sight distances. 
 
7. 
Due  to  hilly  and  mountainous  terrain,  rockfalls  may  occur  in  some  areas.  These  are 
potentially  hazardous  to  vehicles  that  try  to  avoid  them.  In  certain  areas,  structural  measures 
may be necessary such as riprap revetments, rock cladding, or retaining walls.  
 
8. 
Safety  railings  or  post  barriers  are  generally  absent  in  the  winding  segments  of  the 
project  road.  At  a  minimum,  adequate  additional  width  or  wider  sections  at  road  bends  is 
needed to accommodate turning vehicles.

main objective is to ensure a high degree of safety for all new highway schemes before projects 
are  implemented  and  before  any  accidents  happen.  A  qualified  team  reports  on  the  accident 
potential and safety performance.  
 
11.

standard  and  graphical,  and  are  usually  placed  at  visible  spots  for  easy  recognition  and 
understanding,  as  well  as  to  warn  drivers  of  road  conditions.  Traffic  markings  are  painted 
information  features  on  the  road  pavement  and  may  be  in  addition  to  traffic  signs  along  the 
roadside.  Most  pertinent  to  safety  are  danger  warning  signs  that  alert  drivers  to  possible  road

curvature, or environmental conditions. Signs also show the direction of traffic flow and parking 
places,  and  identify  points  of  interest  including  rest  areas.  Rest  areas  combined  with  service 
facilities (i.e., parking lot, fuel and vehicle maintenance station, communication center, sanitary 
equipment, hotel, or restaurant) are integrated in the road construction. Visibility of these road 
signs  at  a  sufficient  distance  is  important.  As  the  project  road  will  include  international  traffic,

1. 
Monitoring and evaluation have two objectives. The first is to set firm goals and monitor 
their  achievement  during  implementation  to  ensure  achievement  of  the  maximum  positive 
impact for potential beneficiaries. One year after project completion, assessment of whether the 
goals  were  achieved  is  equally  important,  and  provides  input  for  future  projects.  If  the  goals 
were  unrealistic,  they  will  need  to  be  modified  for  future  projects.  Alternatively,  problems  may 
result from the approach and methods used rather than the goals.  

2. 
The second objective is to ensure that the Project does not inadvertently bring harm to 
those affected by it. As a result, a series of social protections are planned to be implemented. 
Success in avoiding harm must also be monitored and evaluated. 

3. 
The  design  and  monitoring  framework  for  the  Project  (Appendix  1)  provides  a  broad 
context  within  which  monitoring  of  socioeconomic  impacts  in  the  project  impact  area  will  be 
conducted.  The  project  performance  monitoring  system  (Table  A13)  provides  the  monitoring 
structure for the Project within which socioeconomic monitoring will be conducted. 

4. 
Baseline  Data.  To  measure  the  project’s  impact,  baseline  data  on  the  project  impact 
area  was  collected  during  the  household  and  village  surveys  carried  out  during  the  project 
preparatory  technical  assistance.  The  data  should  be  sufficient  to  test  economic  and  social 
impacts, including such categories as average monthly income, average number of animals per 
household, household assets, average monthly savings, and number of poor households. 

Project  Monitoring.  Many  of  the  targeted  outputs  are  jobs  created  for  local  residents

and  workers  from  poor  households.  This  data  should  be  collected  from  the  construction 
contractors on an annual basis to monitor whether targets are being met and to take corrective 
measures  as  necessary.  District  governments  should  be  asked  to  record  the  number,  size, 
turnover,  and  tax  revenue  from  businesses  formed  to  serve  the  construction  work  camps  and 
company  staff.  They  should  also  describe  the  extent  of  informal  income-generating  activities 
serving  the  workers,  and  physical  assets  the  construction  contractors  have  provided  to  local 
communities. This information should be provided in an annual report to the Ministry of Roads, 
Transport and Tourism. 

6. 
To  monitor  the  social  protection  objectives,  each  district  government  should  submit  a 
brief  annual  report  certifying  that  work  camp  inspections  were  made  and  noting  any  problems

counseling programs related to HIV/AIDS1 and other communicable diseases conducted at the

Some important secondary benefits from potential development activities generated as a 
result of the road upgrading are not included in the economic analysis of the Project. Once they

8. 
Although  only  an  open  pit  tungsten  mine  (Khovd  Gol)  is  currently  operating  in  western 
Bayan-Olgiy, a silver deposit near Tsagaannuur in northeastern Bayan-Olgiy is being evaluated 
and may be developed within the next several years. The silver mine (Asgat) has a reserve of 
approximately  2,300  tons,  but  is  located  in  a  remote  area  that  is  not  easily  accessible.  Most 
promising  and  commercially  viable  is  a  coal  deposit  with  an  estimated  reserve  of  300  plus 
million tons, which is located near Hovd aimag (Khusheet). The coal and silver mined may be 
exported to the People’s Republic of China, Russian Federation, or other countries, resulting in 
the  increase  of  foreign  reserves  and  gross  domestic  product,  thereby  positively  impacting  the 
overall economic development of the country. The development of mines will positively impact 
employment in the region. Skilled and unskilled labor will be needed to mine the silver or coal, to 
provide support services to the mine, and to transport the minerals to their ultimate destination.

I. 

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
In  the  Economic  Growth  Support  and  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy  (2003),  the  Government  of  Mongolia  emphasizes  road 
network  development  because  roads  play  a  significant  role  in  accelerating  economic  growth  and  reducing  poverty.  In  the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) country strategy and program (2006–2008) for Mongolia, road development is identified as 
important  for  regional  market  integration  and  facilitating  the  movement  of  people,  goods,  and  services  thus  leading  to 
economic development and poverty reduction.  
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                         Poverty Classification: General intervention 
According  to  the  national  household  survey—the  2006  household  income  and  expenditure  survey—32.2%  of  Mongolia’s 
population  is  living  below  the  poverty  line  and  38.7%  in  the  western  region.  In  Bayan-Olgiy,  53%  of  the  population  have 
monthly consumption expenditure below the poverty line of MNT20,200 and in Hovd 46%. According to the social survey of 
the project area, all aimags (provinces) rank the rehabilitation of international and local access roads as a top priority in their 
development agenda. Due to the proximity to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and Russian Federation, Bayan-Olgiy and 
Hovd aimags import about 75% of their energy, food, consumer goods, and construction materials from the two countries. The 
Project will greatly contribute to improved linkages to markets in the PRC, Russian Federation, and Kazakhstan through the 
Russian Federation; and improved access to industrial and tourism employment opportunities and social services. The Project 
will lead to lower transport costs, better access to deliver essential goods from neighboring economies to local communities, 
and employment opportunities during construction. The following are common issues in the area related to poverty:  

(i)  High unemployment. Lack of job opportunities is one of the main issues. In the western region, the unemployment 
rate was 5.3% in 2004, compared with 3.6% in the country. No significant industry is currently in place to boost the 
regional economy.  

(ii)  Poor  medical  facilities.  Every  soum  (local  administrative  division)  has  trained  medical  assistants  and  primary 
health care centers with minimal facilities. However, problems still remain because of the lack of modern facilities for 
special  treatment  at  clinics  and  hospitals,  nurses  and  doctors  have  not  been  fully  trained  in  modern  treatment 
techniques, and costs for medical treatment are higher for poor households in the region.  

(iii)  Unsecured  drinking  water  resource.  In  Bayan-Olgiy  aimag,  12.8%  of  households  have  access  to  water  from 
water  distribution  stations,  compared  with  94.5%  of  households  in  Hovd  aimag;  the  remainder  use  water  from 
natural (unprotected) sources such as springs, rivers, and lakes.  

II. 

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Strategy to Address Social Issues 
1.  Create  Local  Job  Opportunities.  The  implementing  agency  will  require  contractors  to  maximize  hiring  labor  under  the 
Project.  The  Project  will  generate  about  1,300  unskilled  construction  jobs:  80%,  or  1,040  jobs,  will  be  targeted  for  poor 
households.  In  addition,  a  separate  community-based  local  road  and  maintenance  project  funded  by  the  Japan  Poverty 
Reduction Fund will be implemented to generate additional local employment.  
2.  Improve Medical Facilities and Drinking Water Resources. The Project allocates $150,000 for community development 
activities in the project area to respond to social needs such as drinking water development, public baths, vocational training, 
and equipment for community-based enterprises.  

B.  Consultation and Participation 

1.  Provide a summary of the consultation and participation process during project preparation. 
More  than  6,200  people  were  consulted  during  project  preparation  through  public  meetings  and  socioeconomic  surveys. 
Various stakeholders participated in the consultation process,  such as central  and  local government officials, environmental 
experts,  social  workers,  teachers,  doctors,  herders,  business  persons,  and  road  users.  Active  participation  from  women  in 
public meetings was confirmed during the fact-finding mission. These processes have enabled: (i) increased awareness and 
local  support,  (ii)  expression  of  opinions  and  concerns  on  social  and  environmental  aspects,  (iii)  relevant  suggestions  for 
western  region  and  local  road  designs  (e.g.,  road  alignments  and  access  roads)  and  future  road  projects,  and 
(vi) identification of potential community development projects.

C.  Gender and Development 

1.  Key Issues.  
Women  in  the  western  aimags  do  not  currently  experience  gender  problems  in  terms  of  women’s  rights  and  access  to 
education,  health,  and  other  services.  However,  the  country  gender  assessment  identifies  growing  concerns  on  emerging 
gender gaps. Despite women’s higher rate of participation in the workforce and educational attainment, the per capita gross 
domestic  product  for  women  is  half  of  that  for  men  ($2,730  versus  $1,379)  according  to  2006  Gender  Gaps  Report  by  the 
World Economic Forum. A factor is women’s predominant occupation in contracting sectors and men’s dominance in growth 
sectors.  Other  gender  concerns  are  (i)  significantly  higher  incidence  of  poverty  among  households  headed  by  women,  (ii) 
women’s unemployment rate is double that of men, and (iii) time poverty caused by increased demand for rural women’s labor 
in food production for household consumption. Also the incidence of domestic violence and alcohol abuse is growing.
